choices.D:
Add Leaf2 and Leaf3 node IDs under switch profile SW_Prof.
Map Int_Selec under Int_Prof.
Assign policy group to interface profile Int_Prof.
choices.A:
Map switch selector SW_Selec under switch profile SW_Prof.
Add Leaf2 and Leaf3 node IDs under switch selector SW_Selec.
Assign policy group to interface selector Int_Selec.
choices.C:
Create the explicit VPC group from fabric policies.
Map interface Eth1/1 under interface selector Int_Selec.
Assign policy group to interface selector Int_Selec.
choices.E:
Create the explicit VPC group from access policies.
Map Interface Eth1/1 under interface selector Int_Selec.
Map Int_Selec under Int_Prof.
choices.B:
Add Leaf2 and Leaf3 node IDs under switch selector SW_Selec.
Map switch profile SW_Prof under switch selector SW_Selec.
Create the explicit VPC group from access policies.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A Cisco ACI fabric has these configurations:
• VPC exists between Leaf2 and Leaf3.
• A switch profile called SW_Prof exists.
• A switch selector called SW_Selec exists.
• An interface selector named Int_Selec exists.
• An interface profile named Int_Prof exists.

Which two sets of actions must the engineer perform to connect Server1 to Leaf2 and Leaf3 using VPC? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: i believe that when they say' switch selector' - this is actually termed ' leaf selector' in the APIC. i agree A and E

Selected Answer: AE
Horrible question from Cisco again. AE looks correct.

Selected Answer: AE
AE is correct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer plans to upgrade the Cisco ACI fabric. Leaf1 and Leaf2 are deployed in a VPC. The fabric is peering with R1 using BGP protocol. Which two actions upgrade the fabric nondisruptively? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
It is A and D.. I just checked it
Graceful Upgrade can be Enforced or Unenforced
Maintenance mode is not used for update

Selected Answer: A
Only correct answer is A….D is not correct unless it is a typo, putting a switch in maintenance does not help upgrading it.

Selected Answer: AD
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/4-x/rest-api-config/Cisco-APIC-REST-API-Configuration-Guide-401/Cisco-APIC-REST-API-Configuration-Guide-401_chapter_01001.pdf

If you put a switch in maintenance mode, that switch is not considered as a part of the operational ACI
fabric infra and it will not accept regular APIC communications. Therefore, performing a firmware
upgrade for a switch in this state is not supported, since it may fail or may get stuck in an incomplete
status indefinitely if you attempt to perform a firmware upgrade on it while it is in this state.
A and D: Graceful Insertion and Removal, cannot be used for Upgrades, it is meant for isolation, debugs...

choices.B: Disable the BGP neighborship between Cisco ACI fabric and R1.
choices.D: Configure one maintenance group for every leaf.
choices.E: Create one update group for all spines.
choices.C: Enable the Graceful Insertion and Removal option.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In Cisco ACI, when a load balancer is performing source and destination NAT and is connected to the fabric using a single interface, traffic must be explicitly redirected through the load balancer for both inbound and outbound flows. This ensures that the load balancer processes traffic in both directions, maintaining consistent NAT mappings.
To achieve this, Policy-Based Redirect (PBR) must be applied on the contract between the consumer EPG (host A) and provider EPG (host B). PBR ensures that traffic is redirected to the load balancer before reaching its destination.
I think, A is correct answer

choices.B: Disable unicast routing on the bridge domain BD_2.
choices.C: Configure limit IP learning to subnet on BD_3.
choices.A: Apply PBR on contract between the load balancer and application EPGs.
choices.D: Set the default gateway for host B on the load balancer.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A load balancer is connected to the Cisco ACI fabric using a single interface. The load balancer is performing source and destination NAT. A service graph is configured on the Cisco ACI. Which action must be taken to allow traffic from host A to pass through the load balancer before reaching host B?

choices.D: Configure Spine-1 as the MP-BGP route reflector.
choices.B: Implement a contract between the Server 2 EPG and the L3Out.
choices.C: Implement the bridge domain to advertise the bridge domain subnet.
choices.A: Configure 10.2.2.0/24 under the external EPG of the L3Out.

discussion.content: D - as it mentions specific subnet 2.2.2.0 and "other subnets"

comments.content: yes, it is clear that it is needed to activate MP_BGP, but the question is referring to be sure that leaf-2 subnets are learned by the external network, so a contract is needed to deploy pervasive gw on the border leaf.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Cisco ACI fabric is connected to a Cisco Catalyst 3850 Series Switch using EBGP. Server 2 is unable to communicate with Server 1. Leaf-2 fails to learn the external subnet 10.2.2.0/24 and other external subnets from other L3Outs. Which configuration ensures that the networks from Leaf-2 are learned by the external network?

choices.D:
Select Event Severity Assignment Policies.
Set severity level to cleared.
choices.C:
Select Faults Severity Assignment Policies.
Set severity level to squelched.
choices.A:
Select Faults Severity Assignment Policies.
Set severity level to cleared.
choices.B:
Select Event Severity Assignment Policies.
Set severity level to squelched.

comments.content:
Step 1 
Navigate to the monitoring policy that is affected by the event.

Step 2 
Expand the monitoring policy and select Event Severity Assignment Policies.

Step 3 
From the Monitoring Object drop-down list, select the object that contains the event to be changed.

Step 4 
In the task bar at the top of the policy table, click the + sign.

A form row appears in the table.

Step 5 
Select the desired event code in the Code drop-down list.

Step 6 
Select the desired severity level in the Severity drop-down list.

To prevent the event from appearing in event reports, select squelched.

Step 7 
(Optional) To make a notation about the change, you can add a comment in the Description text box.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/all/faults/guide/b_APIC_Faults_Errors/b_IFC_Faults_Errors_chapter_010.html#id_65146

In some cases, you might want to ignore a particular event and squelch (suppress) it from appearing in event reports or status dashboards. APIC provides two locations from which you can change the severity of an event type:

In a monitoring policy (beginning with Cisco APIC Release 3.2(1))

Directly from the Events tab under a component in the APIC GUI (beginning with Cisco APIC Release 4.2(1))

For squelching an event, we recommend using this procedure instead of the procedure described in Changing Event Severity or Squelching an Event in the Monitoring Policy.

Selected Answer: B
The question is about events, not faults.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/all/faults/guide/b_APIC_Faults_Errors/b_IFC_Faults_Errors_chapter_010.html#id_65146

questions.question_text: An engineer created a monitoring policy called Test in a Cisco ACI fabric and had to change the severity level of the monitored object Call home source. Which set of actions prevent the event from appearing in event reports?
